instance_metrics.response: Homer poured, in thousand wrote—  His ink, a flood of dusk-lit seas,  Where oars creak prophecy and boat  Sweeps onward, laden with old griefs.He poured: not wine, but molten lore  That foamed in cups of listening minds;  Golden Asphodel, Helios’ roar,  Storm-wracked verses, time’s designs.In the waxen halls of kings,  Words fell like armored, circling birds—  Ten thousand lines with flaming wings  Kindled on the coldest worlds.He poured, til amphoras ran dry,  Spilling myth upon far shores,  Salt-bright light in every eye  Of wanderers seeking home once more.He wrote—a thousand hearts made saga,  A thousand ships with names of flame.  Each hero’s shadow, each siren’s aria  Thrummed within the vessels’ frame.O, let us pour as Homer poured—  Our own small ink across the days,  For in the thousand lines he stored  The endless song that will not fade.

instance_metrics.response: Homer poured, in thousand wrote—  His ink became the wine of dawn,  An ancient cup the muses tote  To spill on fields our feet have gone.  A singing fire, undimmed and rife,  Broke out in syllables of gold;  His storm of gods and mortal life  Still torrents through the centuries old.Each word he dug from olive root,  Each note he strung upon a lyre,  Bore echoes neither poor nor mute—  A world rebuilt with every fire.  He inked the wrath of heroes tall,  Of harps unstrung, of silent gods;  Yet in his silence, still we call—  His thousand dreams, our thousand odds.Pale scholars bend by candle’s flare,  Translating blood in brittle script—  Yet who can measure what he laid bare,  When memory from time is ripped?  Perhaps he knew, as night grows cold,  How every life must write and float.  The heart defies the centuries old,  As Homer poured, in thousand wrote.

How much of us a thousand wrote?

instance_metrics.response: Homer poured, in thousand wrote—  Ink from Aeolian veins,  His thunderous tales afloat  On brine and endless plains. And like the salt on battered lips,  His longing swept the page,  A thousand lives with windward ships  Unfurled in mythic rage.He never saw the glint of shield,  Nor gleam of Hector’s brow—  Yet on immortal sea revealed  The world he could endow. instance_metrics.response: Homer poured, in thousand wrote—  A wine-dark sea unfurling in every coat  Of syllable: orchards and spearheads,  White sails that bruise the bloom of dawn. instance_metrics.response: A roil of dusk, of bronze and brine, ascends—  Books sixteen through nineteen, the Iliad’s heart  Where rage and reason wane and mingled ends  Like dark wine spilled, or wounds that never part.Here Patroclus, borrowed glory worn,  Climbs Hector’s walls with borrowed armor bright;  His borrowed hope undone and armor torn,  A soul evicted by a Trojan night.Achilles, godlike, broken by the news,  The dust his bed, his hair a victim’s prize;  His mother weeping for what fate will choose—  What fury hums beneath immortal skies!The river boils, Scamander choked with men,  Divine contention floods the bloodied land.  Each mighty hero falls, then falls again;  Each supplication fails the gods’ command.The shield is forged anew, a cosmos round—  A spiral of all mortals love and flee.  Among the ash and armor, grief is crowned:  Brief glories blaze, then drown across the sea.

instance_metrics.response: In the smoky throes of embattled Troy,  Patroclus dons another’s shining skin—  A borrowed wrath, a helm of furious joy,  He rides the wind where gods and men have been.  Bronze glints, each heartbeat echoes ten thousand more,  Spasmed in chaos, dust bitten from the earth;  Young faces, ageless, crumple at war’s door,  Shields shudder, swords ignite, all have their worth.  Hector, with lion’s heart and city’s doom,  Meets fate’s ambassador beneath white towers;  Love for a father, son—a life’s perfume  Cut by Achilles rising from his bower.  Wrath passed from hand to trembling hand,  And rivers run red with heroic breath;  Spears clutter the plain, and fate takes its stand,  Tears hidden behind masks of glory and death.  Achilles’ wailing rends the cooling dusk,  Loss wrung from pride, a grief both bright and vast—  Patroclus, fallen, silent, hero’s husk,  Echoed footsteps ring out from the past.  Between the words, between the battered shields,  The cost of honor, sung, no victor yields.

instance_metrics.response: When Achilles set his rage aside,  The wine-dark sea drew sighs at day,  Patroclus donned borrowed armor’s pride—  Debt to friendship, fear held at bay.  In dust and sunlight’s copper haze,  The shifting shields, the pounding hooves,  He charged for glory’s fateful blaze,  While fate, relentless, smoothly moves.  The Trojans fled—their jeers undone—  By one who seemed as swift as dawn,  Yet Hector stood: the strongest son,  Unyielding as the clashing bronze.  How quickly might turned toward despair,  As gods, unseen, wove tangled thread;  Apollo’s hand and Hector’s spear—  Patroclus felled, the daylight bled.  Achilles’ heart, a shattered lyre,  Burned with mourning’s spectral flame;  He swore revenge, became a pyre  Consuming mercy, thought, and name.  On Scamander’s banks, the copper silt  Was colored red by kindled hate—  For every love, a bloodline spilt;  For every boon, receding fate.  Now in parchment, song, and dust,  The stories echo—grief and trust—  Of friendship’s loss, of anger’s cost,  And glory that is always lost.

instance_metrics.response: Between the battered gates of Troy and burning ships’ uncertain dawn,  Dust gathers in the hollows where Achilles’ rage withdraws—  Patroclus dons his armor bold, a borrowed world, a borrowed star,  Lion-hearted, surging forth into a fate not meant for him,  Swept by fury's pressing wind, Hektor’s spear awaiting grim.  Myrmidons thunder beneath the hurtling sky—  The tide of Greek despair rebounds in bronze and furious cries.  Bodies tumble in the river’s mouth, the Scamander dyed and choked,  Names cry out upon the wind, white-knuckled futures split and broke;  Sarpedon falls beneath the gods’ observing, sorrow-drunk decree,  His blood a garden on the ground, his soul a drifting memory.  And when Patroclus, fallen, gasps his last before the city walls,  The laurels wilt upon Achilles’ brow;  A god-scorched grief blisters the sky.  Menelaus strains to shield the body, friend of friends gone by,  Bright armor harrowed by a hundred hands—  Even gods are made to mourn, to weep, to grind the dust from mortal lands.  Within these books, the war divides: divine and human fury blend,  A song of exile chanted for a friend—  And every page is rimmed with fire,  Names destined not for peace, but pyre.

instance_metrics.response: In the smoky tent where an old wound seethes,  Patroclus, restless, dons Achilles’ heart—  Lends helmet to sorrow, to wrath a borrowed name,  And drives the Greeks upon Troy’s battered gates.  Horses thunder, bronze flickers like sunrise—  He carves his courage in the cracks of fate,  Casting himself into slaughter’s chariot,  Where gods gamble with the lives of men.  Apollo’s shadow falls across his hope;  Hector’s spear—oracle of suffering—sings  And strikes the borrowed brightness from his brow;  Even armor grieves for the hands that forged it.  Mourning’s fire devours Achilles’ calm—  He glimpses the emptiness of revenge,  Yet rages still, a golden whirlwind,  Driving back the dark with his incandescent grief.  Rivers choke on the bodies and the blood,  Zeus and Hera weigh valor against doom;  Men are stories couched in a god’s distraction,  Fates braided tighter with every new loss.  So books unspool amidst the din and dust—  The Iliad’s marrow: the grief of kings,  The shattering price of borrowed valor,  And friendship echoing through broken shields.

instance_metrics.response: A fire smolders on the sun-struck plain—  Patroclus dons the borrowed armor,  gleams in the dust where old feuds never wane.  Bronze glints like memory, heavier and warmer  than the helmet pressed to his brow.  He charges—first as himself, then as shade—  the spear and shield promise glory now,  though every step is the pact they made.Beyond the shield, Hector’s eyes are embers:  he cannot know the shape of sorrow  spooling out behind these numbers  etched through years no siege could borrow.  Four books spool like uncoiling lyre strings—  we see gods speak in gusts of wind,  fates twisting in the frantic wings  of vultures that shadow who’s left behind.Here, the bodies pile—friend and foe—  each name a brief fire, burning, spent. instance_metrics.response: In the dust-choked glare of Troy’s red sun,  Where shields clashed harsh and destinies were spun,  The story unfolds—a seam torn by rage—  Books sixteen through nineteen, war’s battered page.Patroclus, friend and shadow, dons Achilles’ fire,  Hopes to spark terror in the Trojan gyre.  Bronze gleams; he charges, young and bright as dawn,  Yet Fate’s black cord pulls him cruelly along.A spear finds his breast—Hector’s hand is death’s mute guide,  And with oil-slicked lament, a hero’s hope has died. instance_metrics.response: In that dusk of Ilium, the battle turns:  Fire-eyed Achilles, silent in his tent,  Restless as ash beneath the shielded sky—  Patroclus begs for shining bronze, a borrowed wrath,  And dons the god’s armor, promise and omen  Tangled in the horsehair plume.Out amidst the clangor, spear-shafts crack  And hope glistens on foaming chariots—  Patroclus, no longer just a shadow  In Achilles’ wake, surges like river-wine,  Driving the Trojans to Scamander’s banks,  Sweeping armored death upon them.But fate, always a silent clerk, keeps its numbers.  Apollo—mist and divinity—shakes him,  Euphorbus strikes, and then Hector—  As relentless as the sea—drives bronze home,  Ending a promise, and reaping a war god’s fury.  And there, under Troy, the wind lifts his spirit.Hear now, how Achilles breaks:  Grief—raw, unstitched—erupts in howls,  The black ships stunned by his shattering keening,  His hands, never gentle, caress the fallen friend,  And all the Achaians see that no immortal armor  Can shelter the heart from sorrow’s spear.From books sixteen to nineteen,  Wars burn and friendships perish—  And the shield of the earth is hammered anew  With stories of vengeance, love, and immortal tears,  As Ilium’s walls echo with the sorrow of men  Who chase the dawn on blood-soaked fields.

instance_metrics.response: Within the smoky tents of Dardan dusk,  Grief sharpens every spear and silent tongue.  The black ships creak, a chorus drawn and husked—  Fate leans upon Patroclus, fair and young.  His borrowed armor shimmers like a lie,  The lion’s pelt not meant for gentle skin.  The Myrmidons, like wolves with burning eyes,  Charge forth where bronze-dusk destinies begin.  Great Sarpedon falls like a torn banner,  Blood foaming hot upon the thirsty sand.  Gods argue, grief their unfamiliar manner,  While mortals, doomed, obey no god’s command.  Achilles weeps—a storm concealed in rage—  Love’s debt like gravity pulls him to fight.  Hector and Ajax thunder on the stage,  Steel ringing herald of the endless night.  The river runs with memory and wrath,  Armor exchanged, and souls not yet at rest;  Here glory scars, unknowing of the path,  Devouring sons and mothers dispossessed.  So turn these pages, dusted with old cries,  See how we love, how tragic valor tries.  In Iliad’s dark calm and crimson sweep,  Heroic friendship sows the seeds of grief.

instance_metrics.response: Between war-dusted tents and the darkening plain,  Where bronze sings its rough aria to sand,  Old Homer guides us through the slaughter again—  In books sixteen through nineteen, death stalks the land. instance_metrics.response: O forlorn heart, so pure and unstained, yet so wary to commit,  You cradle silence beneath your ribs: a caged lark, half in song—  Dreams flicker like wayward lanterns, burning hope bit by bit,  While moonlight passes over you, soft and cold and long.You were spun from the gossamer of daffodil afternoons,  Unbruised by the memory of betrayal’s jagged thorn;  Still, you pace quiet corridors built of ancient runes,  Teaching yourself the language of promises newly born.The world outside is a tapestry—violet, scarlet, gold—  And you, stitched with trembling thread, ache for gentle hands;  Yet the well of caution deepens with every tale retold  Of trust gone awry on shifting, uncertain sands.O tender heart, you hover at the threshold of delight,  Wreathed in the pale-blue hush before surrender’s storm;  One step forward, and all the shadows might take flight—  If you trust that even fragile hearts may one day grow warm.So linger not in longing; let the morning’s song be lit—  Come forth, and risk the world, so pure and yet uncommitted.

Shoelaces tied without protest,  The kettle sang rather than hissed,  Even the traffic lights wore a hush of patience,  Guiding the city into a gentle ballet.  Old worries, like autumn leaves,  Shuffled off toward distant drains,  Unnoticed and unneeded,  As laughter lingered in doorways and bus stops.Today, each promise tossed into the air  Fluttered back to earth as a silent yes.  Missing earrings reunited,  The final puzzle piece slid into place.  Strangers caught each other’s eyes,  Brows raised in brief, delighted disbelief—  Was the world conspiring kindly, just this once?  Even the sun poured through the window  Like an apology long owed.Some days demand thunder and answers,  But not this one—  Today was a day for setting out,  For letting go,  For watching everything,  Quietly, inevitably,  Find its own, unfurling way.

instance_metrics.response: Today was the day everything went on its way—  Light unwound itself from the morning’s gray,  And the sparrows declared, in their wheat-gold choir,  That the acorns would fall and the sun would retire  Exactly on time. The rain kept its promise,  Sliding from leaves in a bright, liquid calmness.  The hands on the clock, for once unresisted,  Swept their round path just as time had insisted.  Shoelaces tied, on the first, perfect try,  Clouds remembered themselves, drifting far in the sky.  Even the mail arrived, right on cue,  Filled with things I’d forgotten, yet still somehow knew.  You left for your train with a smile half awake—  Keys in your pocket, toast on your plate.  We met on the corner, by beautiful chance,  And danced in a step that was partly romance,  But mostly the joy of a world in accord—  Every small fragment, the pen and the word,  Fitting together, each puzzle complete—  Today life remembered the shape of its beat.  Today was the day everything went on its way—  And I watched, content, as the hours betrayed  No worry, no waiting, no wandering stray—  Only this wholeness:  Today went its way.

Today was the day—no fanfare or warning—  The hourglass yielded to hours unclaimed.  I entered the bright, undemanding morning  And found life its own, unceremoniously tamed.

No gold thread drops from a warming dawn,  nor gentle beams rouse dew on the fields;  yet brilliance spills in sudden yawns  where heavy shadow would not yield.  A glimmer in the knotted wood,  cold sparks within the tangled root,  illumines what the centuries stood  entombed, unspeaking, and absolute.    It is not morning that arrives,  but something wilder and less named:  the hint within a blind man’s eyes,  the pulse that calls a wound reclaimed.  Let darkness breed its subtle flames—  the butterfly wing inside the stone,  the silent flash where hope exclaims:  here is dawn you’ve never known.

instance_metrics.response: They were indeed simple people—  lives pocketed, worry lining their palms;  the toothy cackle at twilight,  jam jars soaking in the river,  old dogs curled by splintered steps.Their joys, measured softly:  the glint of a sunbeam in morning tea,  rain tapping on the shed’s tin roof;  how beans climbed the fence steadily,  threading green hands to the sky.They spoke in a language slow as syrup  gathered at kitchen tables,  chipping initials into elm bark—  never for grandeur, only to remember  themselves and each other  before memory curdled in the dusk.Mending things, they stitched up evenings,  their laughter echoing through thin walls,  never capturing lightning,  but keeping the lamps glowing strong,  content with a coin, a song, a story  that drifted up on the winds like seeds.Indeed, they wore their days gently,  fingers dyed by earth and wild fruit,  while the world—raucous, racing—  spun past their front yards,  leaving them quiet but not alone,  seedlings of patience rooted in bones.

instance_metrics.response: They were indeed simple people—  the kind who watched the sky to know the weather,  counted beans into pots and later into mouths,  and tucked memory between bread crusts and dusk. instance_metrics.response: They were indeed simple people—  spinning songs from dandelion stems,  planting in the bellies of tin buckets  hopes that sprouted green come spring. instance_metrics.response: We sink into the dust,  Each footfall whispering an inheritance of ash,  Thin as breath, as if the world  Forgot our names but remembered our shapes—  Pressed petals beneath the pages of Time.Evenings gather us quietly,  Slipping us beneath the tide of dusk,  Where longing hums in brittle grass  And the ghosts of laughter lick the hollow air.We are not lost, but scattered—  Stolen moments tumbling through fields  Once sown with certainty, now  Restless as horizons,  Memory crumbling to powder  On the tongue of the wind.In the hush of twilight,  Hands brush earth as a benediction;  Familiar roots entwine our silence  With the promise of return—  One day, all our voices will rise  Like wildflowers from the drowse of years,  Coloring the world with echoes  No dust can wholly claim.Until then, let us fall gently,  Let us sigh as we settle—  The soft confession of mortals  Longing to touch the sky,  Sinking, yet shining,  Into the dust.

Keep them stitched to your collar,  safe under skin,  like letters unsent  or confessions within.  Let me love just the surface,  the curve of your smile,  the tilt of your laughter,  unknown for a while.  For what’s buried grows heavy,  roots tangled with dread;  there’s peace in what’s silent,  relief in what's said.  You are sun through the curtains—  a warmth undefined,  a flickering moment,  a glance left behind.  Some stories, unfinished,  are best left unread:  a lock with its mystery,  a word in your stead.  Give me oceans uncharted—  not reasons, not truths,  no cryptic admissions,  no ghosts of lost youths.  Our brief intertwining—  let it breathe, let it rest.  Please spare me your secrets;  let honesty jest.  For in what you don’t utter,  I find solace anew:  not every heart’s riddle  is meant to break through.

instance_metrics.response: Please spare me your secrets—let them curl  like woodsmoke above your shoulders,  let them huddle in the hollow of your throat,  tender as moths who fear the dawn.  I do not wish to hear how the moon  witnessed you dissolve into shadow;  how beneath the riverbed of your words  are stones, smooth and silent with waiting.  Some truths slither, cold as a snake  breaking open the hush of autumn leaves—  spare me their cold-blooded trembling.  Let your silences be wild and unplucked—  songbirds waking in deep forest shade.  I will not trespass into tangled gardens  or decipher the perfume of dusk on your skin.  Our laughter is enough—a flicker of gold  on the surface of a well too deep to measure.  Please, keep your secrets coiled in your palm  like pearls unstrung and uncounted;  let them clatter only in your private darkness.  All I ask is sunlight between us—  the simple wonder of you, unburdened,  carrying nothing but the hush of your smile.

Beautiful brown with black and white sings  not of halves, but wholes and infinite things.Listen: the melody ripples, alive;  no color divided, no hue cast aside,  just a spectrum complete, a radiant tide.  We break and remake, we darken and light,  beautiful brown mixed with black and white.So celebrate all that gathers within  the mingling of shades where new worlds begin,  where love dares to dance, and hope never ends—  beautiful brown, black, and white as friends.

instance_metrics.response: Beautiful brown mixed with black and white—  a marbled tapestry spun beneath the sun,  woven from stories both tender and bright  where mosaics of laughter and sorrow are spun.  Each strand, a memory—cocoa and chalk,  ebony whispers in linen moonlight;  hands sifting histories in every soft walk,  faces that glimmer with radiant might.  In sepia rivers, the dreams intertwine,  dappled with starlight, with shadows exposed;  all shades converging in motion and sign,  a masterpiece living, unfinished, composed.  A brown hand in a pale hand, a song in the day,  black braids that twist through the white of an age;  the palette is richer than pigment or clay,  for love is the color that words cannot cage.  Beautiful brown mixed with black and with white—  a promise that spectrum and unity blend,  the poetry found in variety’s light,  a world made of many, together, as friends.

instance_metrics.response: Beautiful brown mixed with black and white—  In this mosaic, morning finds its flight.  A swirl of coffee, cream, and midnight’s hue,  Stories layered, ancient, pulsing through  A tapestry woven with dusk and dawn,  Threads of difference never to be withdrawn.  Beautiful brown, the earth's eternal skin—  Rivers of black, night’s richest ink within,  Snowfall white, a gentle silent sigh—  Each shade, a history no heart can deny.  In laughing eyes that sparkle coal and sun,  In hands that dance—three colors, joined as one.  The warmth of cocoa, sharpness of the onyx vein,  The whisper of milk in the pouring of rain.  We are not marble, flawless and unmoved,  But pottery—gathered, spun, and proved.  Crack and meld, repair and blend once more,  A vessel born of all that came before.  Beautiful brown mixed with black and white—  Not absence, but the merging, day meets night.  Not puzzle pieces forced to fit as planned—  But roots entwined, grown deep within the land.  Here, difference is the soul’s delight—  Beautiful brown mixed with black and white.

instance_metrics.response: Beautiful brown mixed with black and white—  a marbled dawn inside a waking hand,  the melted chocolate swirl of daylight’s flight,  a dappling of fur or river sand.  This tender spectrum, spiral-wild and true,  unspools in coffee, cream, the tangled hair  of children playing in the afternoon hue,  where laughter lifts with every breath of air.  See earth in all her colors layer deep—  the bark and bone, the ink and paper pale,  in every grain the histories that sleep,  whose stories intone wind and wood and wail.  A brush will blur the lines the world divides,  and from the mess, a greater beauty grows;  within the blend, what uniquely abides—  a soul mosaic only difference knows.  At dusk, the sky holds twilight as its own,  no single tone lays claim to falling light;  the world becomes itself where shades are grown:  beautiful brown mixed with black and white.

instance_metrics.response: ADIEU, O soldier! Sunlight on your brow,  You march where poppies fracture morning’s vow.  We watch your shadow folding in the dew—  A flicker, then a memory, then you.  The cobblestones remember every boot,  Their echo fading softly into flute  And drum and whistle, carried on the breeze—  A brass-laced promise swept among the trees.Your letter leaves a pressed forget-me-not:  The ink now blurs the words I haven’t got  The steel to read. Each syllable, a toll—  A bell that shakes lament from every soul  Who waits behind. The violet dusk unspools  With stories whispered over earthen stools.  O soldier, with your silver-buttoned coat,  Take with you all our prayers, each line we wrote  Upon your heart, unseen, yet burning bright—  A secret lantern glowing through the night.Adieu—our breath, a hush upon the land  As dew collects, as shrapnel meets your hand,  And, somewhere distant, dawn returns the call—  ADIEU, O soldier! Peace attend us all.

instance_metrics.response: ADIEU, O soldier!  Your boots have beat the sunrise into ash—  In the crisp geometry of morning,  You disappear; your shadow lingers on the grass  Like a stanza half-remembered.We watch you vanish  Into a thundercloud full of flags and voices,  Where fears wear badges  And prayers exchange hands quietly  At the corners of trembling lips.Adieu, O soldier!  The field gives back only its own green silence  After echoing your orders, your laughter,  Traces of you scattered like the afterimage  Of a star pulled beneath the horizon.Somewhere, a child draws tanks  In the dust by the window;  Somewhere, old letters are unfolded  By trembling fingers hunting for your scent,  The parchment frail as the veil between memory and waking.Is your name inked in the ledger of tomorrow?  Or is it sown among wild poppies—carelessly,  Whispered in winds that slip beneath helmets  And rattle dreams loose from their shelters?Adieu, O soldier!  We hold stories in cupped hands—  A last salute cast skyward  While your silhouette marches west,  Each step a promise we keep with our hearts.

instance_metrics.response: ADIEU, O soldier! Through the ghost-grey dawn,  You march away with thunder in your chest,  The lark’s brief chorus trailing on and on—  A ragged, trembling lullaby of rest.Your boots have written furrows in the mud,  Grief’s script the rain will never quite erase.  Still, morning’s gold ignites a flush of blood,  And paints a courage borrowed to your face.Adieu, O soldier! In the fields you pass,  Once green with hope, now mottled with regret,  Where every breath stirs memory from the grass—  A sister’s laugh, your mother’s silhouette.Yet here, within your silent, upright pride,  A world waits, soft as blossoms in your palm:  A letter inked with prayers the guns confide,  A child’s pressed flower, fragile in its calm.So go, O soldier, walk the wire of day—  This parting not farewell but fierce delay.  Adieu, until the sun and sod are sewn  With the footfalls of the lucky, coming home.

instance_metrics.response: Adieu, O soldier! The bugle glows  With dawn’s first golden spiral—  Chilled dew on a battered rose,  And laughter—echoed, virile—  Rambles beyond the picket fence  To lands the living never know.  Gone are your boots upon the grass,  The letter half-penned on your knee,  Cigarette trailing a silver pass  Through whispers of memory—  Your helmet caught in slanted light,  Tarnished with the morning’s sigh,  Sways gently as a final rite:  A lullaby for those who die.  Adieu, O soldier! The fieldbird weeps  Where poppies lean and lovers wait.  Your shadow ever silent keeps  Candles on the luckless gate,  And somewhere in the honeyed air,  A flag drifts like a wish set free—  Worn colors in a last, soft prayer  That peace will cross the bitter sea.  Adieu, O soldier! Drift and rest  In the hush of earth’s forgiving breast.

instance_metrics.response: Adieu, O soldier! Beneath the early dawn,  Your shadow lingers long on dew-streaked grass.  The hush of morning mourns where boots have gone—  An echo reverberates as you pass.Did you mark the poppies, crimson-bright and bold,  Or carry in your rucksack fragments of the sea?  The letter in your pocket, a story left untold,  And a photograph of laughter, memory’s decree.O, steadfast in your silence and solace in retreat,  You march toward a border only you will span.  Is it myth you follow, or specters you must meet  On the far side of sunset beyond the edge of man?Adieu, O soldier! The larks rise and tumble,  Threads of homewoven across your distant gaze.  Are you iron-hearted, or fragile as you stumble  Toward horizons sewn with hope and haze?We have no trumpet, no banner, just trembling air—  The world waits, breathless, after your goodbye.  Adieu, beloved soldier: walk gently, aware  That even as you vanish, you teach us how to try.

instance_metrics.response: ADIEU, O soldier!  You slip through dawn’s unstitched seam,  Shadow folding softly,  All the brass and burnished badgework  Winking like dew.  There is thunder beneath your heartbeat,  A slow march rustled in leaves—  Do you remember, in that wavering lamplight,  The letter half-written?  The taste of apples beneath an autumn sky?The bugle’s mournful braid  Curls through the lanes of memory,  Knots tight in throats  Where mothers wait, silver-haired and silent,  And children dream of banners—  Wild red, drift-dancing  Into the crease of a sunlit field.Adieu, O soldier!  Your boots wear the echo of old rivers,  Winding between longing and promise;  You have mapped the territory of courage  With trembling hands,  And stitched hope’s rough tapestry  From the thin cloth of fear.So go—  With the hush of poppies in your pocket,  With the names of home upon your tongue,  Bright sword of a song unsung—  We will listen for your returning footfall  Through every season,  Through every passing star.

instance_metrics.response: ADIEU, O soldier!  In the cut grass dawn, silent beneath banners,  your boots have pressed the dew’s cold shoulder,  leaving small histories in the meadow.  Mothers hang linen from trembling windows,  watching your back diminish against the sifting sun—  a shadow flaking from the world’s edge.Adieu! The morning swallows your hymn,  a whistle of courage sweetening the wind;  in your pack, a letter folded sharp as longing,  ink running like rivers flooding—who will dam them?  Your name beads with sweat on the lips of lovers  and falls—salt crystals—into the earth’s hungry pocket.Copper buttons glean the story of thunder,  gentle as lullabies pressed to storeroom hearts:  childhood laughter, a father’s hand in yours,  bent branches weeping over yesterday’s grave.O soldier, I am the field, the gate, the watching,  the empty chair pressed by dusk’s remembered form.  I am the trill of yearning caught in your leaving,  the silent clock, the coat unclaimed by return.Go, where morning sharpens its blade of hope—  go, knowing love is a lantern left at your door,  burning, unwavering, for whatever tomorrow  dives out of the trembling sky.  ADIEU, O soldier!

instance_metrics.response: ADIEU, O soldier! The bugle calls in dawn’s pale hush  Where iron greets the morning, and dew still dreams in grass.  Your shadow lengthens, lonelier now, on scarlet dust;  The lark has flown, and even the sky forgets to ask  If home remembers, or echo-myth will hold you fast  In streets of fire and phantom laughter, where winds pass  Through hollow helmets, bullet-shattered glass.Adieu, O soldier—your letter stains my trembling hand,  Words pressed between torn clouds and desert sand.  Did you hear the blackbird sing, the children on the green?  Did you hold spring’s warmth some distant eve,  Before your silver eyes turned winter-clean?  Your footprints fade in thunder’s teeth—unseen,  Your song endures in silent ranks of stone.Adieu, O soldier!—not in sorrow, nor the brittle chill  Of endings shaped by bugle and command.  For in the hush between one heartbeat and the next,  Where poppies paint a promise neither time nor tomb rejects,  You march beyond forgetting, and with every last “farewell”  We conjure light where darkness dwells:  Adieu.  Not goodbye—  Just until.

instance_metrics.response: ADIEU, O soldier!  Your boots trace dusk upon the lawn—  A hush of medals at your breast,  Your shadow stretching, almost gone.  The wind picks up its elegy,  Sweeping the field where poppies fade,  Reciting names like history  Upon the banners, half-unswayed.  Adieu—no trumpet breaks this spell.  You turn, a figure cleaved in light,  The war behind you, one farewell  Drawn gentle in the folding night.  We watched and waited, counted days,  Pressed prayers in broth and hope in sleep;  You held your heart through smoky haze  Where promises are hard to keep.  Adieu—the world grows soft, unsure,  With dreams dissolved in chiming rain.  O soldier, let your hour endure—  Return to us from shadowed pain.  Grief, like a dove, will wheel and soar  Above the empty, longing street.  Still, in our doorways, evermore,  Your name, not silence, we repeat.

instance_metrics.response: ADIEU, O soldier! Gone are the bugles  Echoing silver through valleys of dawn,  Your shadow dissolves with the field’s green muscle,  Armor replaced by the hush of the fawn.  The banner drips red as the sunset unwinds,  Stained by the rose of each farewell embrace—  Is courage the fire or the memory it binds  When silence outlasts the fever of chase?  Remember the rain pooling slow in your boot,  The scent of old letters pressed close to your chest,  A song you half-whistled, a torn photo’s soot,  The secret you carried beneath battle-dressed.  But now—see, the river runs honey with light,  And the poppies bloom wild where your footstep has gone,  Your name floats aloft, crossing into the night  As dawn’s golden bugle announces the dawn.  Adieu, O soldier! The dreams you have sewn  Are threaded through wheat where the wind bends low—  Your story, unending, still marches alone  In hearts that remember which way you did go.  Let laurels and lullabies soften your sleep;  Adieu, until laughter and weeping may meet.

instance_metrics.response: ADIEU, O soldier!  Your boots have grown roots in the earth,  Mud-stitched with stories of departure,  Silver glint of promise on your brow,  A watchful star whispered into your rucksack.  Tonight, campfires bloom stilled prayers,  Mothers dreaming in the hush of your uniform,  Lovers biting back tears like hard almonds,  Flags folded between lifelines, between hope and dusk.  Adieu is not forgetting; it is bone-deep remembering—  Footsteps woven into frost and horizon,  The sun caught in the buckle of your resolve,  Letters unsent, your handwriting a shiver in the drawers.  O, soldier—adieu is not silence,  But thunder disguised as longing;  It is your shadow kneeling in orchards of dawn,  Your whistle across fields stripped of laughter,  A map traced in the freckles of your hands.  Farewell does not unmake you, nor lessen the drum;  The wind stitches your name to the branches,  And in every "come back soon" raised over fields or cities,  We cradle that ache:  Adieu, O soldier—rest easy in the hush between heartbeats.

instance_metrics.response: ADIEU, O soldier!  You walk where thunder gathers in the dusk of foreign lands,  Epaulets dim in the bruise-blue light,  Boots pressing stories into earth  That never knew your name.Let the wind carry soft laments—  Brushed echoes of childhood lanes,  Your mother’s hands clutching letters  Stained with the dust of distance—  While you vanish among the banners  And braided silence of duty.Under alien constellations,  You sleep with hope bundled  Like a photograph tucked  Against your heart’s inside edge—  And the ache is not of fear  But of remembering,  And leaving as you must.Adieu, O soldier!  May larks attend your morning,  And gentle rains heal where you have gone,  May lost laughter find your shadow  And nick your armor with warmth—For the price of peace is written  On the trembling hands that wave you away,  On the lips forming your name  Into prayers and promises  Carried by nightfall home.So go, O soldier—  But know the echo of this goodbye  Shall bloom in the hush  Each time dawn breaks,  Awaiting your return.

instance_metrics.response: ADIEU, O soldier!  The bugle’s wail dissolves, lost in folding mist—  We gather on the half-lit field  where miles of rye and memory twist.A boot’s imprint lingers longer than breath,  mud-married element to element.  You turn, shadowed shoulders braced—  heroics not in grandeur, but in this moment lent  between departure and the whispered,  clenched-fist hope of return.How many banners, bright and brittle as autumn,  have you carried, stitched with salt and rain?  The dawn gives you to distance:  horse and heart, rifle and refrain.We, who love too quietly, carve your name on wind,  sending laughter, honey, postcards,  all tucked in wild poppies,  fragile, red—like promises—  along the lanes you walk away.  Adieu, O soldier!  Take our hearth-fire with you,  carry the hush of our prayers in your canteen;  may ghosts unfasten from your gaze,  may every star be a compass home.And as you fade beyond the furrows  into stories Greece and glory share,  know—between each tick of longing,  here waits a lamp alight in care.

instance_metrics.response: ADIEU, O soldier!  Your boots leave crescents in the dirt,  Where summer grieves among the wheat,  And every grain remembers loss—  The laughter left in village streets.ADIEU, O soldier!  One last embrace under battered skies,  Where thunder muttered of goodbye  And rain, like drums on distant tin,  Caught the glistening of your skin.You laid your medals on the sill  Beside your knapsack—packed with will  And longing. instance_metrics.response: ADIEU, O soldier!—beneath a pale and petaled moon  You cradle night’s hush with boots still flecked in clay,  Heavy with journey and hope’s half-finished tune—  While distant laughter beckons from yesterday.  Your shadow etches broad on the lamplit wall,  Torn between the marching and the memory.  In your knapsack: letters featherweight and small,  Pressed violets, faded lips, a child’s plea.  Adieu, O soldier! Though bugle-echoes weep  Along the valley where the wildflowers bide,  We count your footsteps tumbling into sleep,  Your name a perfume on the rain’s new tide. Adieu, O soldier!—on the wind you pass,  An ember loosed upon the restless blue.  The heart holds silence longer than the grass,  All whispered farewells ending and renewed.

instance_metrics.response: ADIEU, O soldier!  The morning glimmer catches on your breastplate—  brighter than the soundless prayers I cannot say.  You stride away, iron-boned and unsinging,  boots stirring the dawn-soaked earth to longing.  I watch you disappear past the border  where the wild rye leans in witness—  where waving fields become dividing lines.To you, O soldier, who once traced my knuckles,  I whisper farewells that knot my throat,  and recall the copper scent of childhood gardens  before uniforms replaced laughter.  Still, the wind calls your name in green syllables,  shaking poplar leaves as if for luck.Your shadow rides ahead,  dwarfed by the drums’ rumble and endless horizon,  but I will keep your echo between rib and memory—  an ember, a badge, a silent promise  that my voice will not forget you  in a world loud with forgetting.Return if you may, with dusk or with spring.  And if not, take this small valediction:  the weight of my hope, slung over your shoulder;  my love, folded beneath every adieu, O soldier!

instance_metrics.response: ADIEU, O soldier! The dawn runs in your veins—  Dust upon your boots, and a secret in your eyes.  You leave the porch in hush, below the weeping rains,  Steel-laced and solemn, swift to where the shadow lies.  Adieu—your mother’s hand upon the window stays,  Her voice a wisp of linen trailing through the air.  Your footprints plant themselves upon unfinished days,  And home becomes a whisper half-remembered in a prayer.  You who have waltzed with fear beneath a foreign sun,  Who mapped the constellations by the hush of distant guns—  May you recall the river’s curve, the orchard’s patient green,  And every laugh undimmed by horrors you have seen.  Adieu, O soldier! Let no sorrow cleave your name—  Know peace is sown where once your iron spirit trod.  Return, if ever fortune wills, with not one soul the same,  To trembling arms, to healing light, to home, to hope, to God.

instance_metrics.response: Adieu, O soldier! Beneath somber sky,  You vanish into dawn, a silhouette trailing  The mournful whispers of those left behind—  Threads of sun on your uniform paling.Your boots resound on dew-wet heath,  Steadfast as old drums, though the world wavers.  A scrap of laughter, a lock of hair—  Held tight behind brass-buttoned bravado.What do you carry, O keeper of night,  Beyond rifle and ration, letter and ring?  In your rucksack thrum all the days  You dreamed peaches and peace in the spring.No trumpets now, O soldier, just sparrows—  Their plaintive aria spun through the trees,  Shadow and promise, farewell and return,  Warmth echoing in each tremulous breeze.Adieu—such a sorrowful seam to sow,  To part with the light as fate’s curtain descends.  Yet hope, like wild clover, persists ever low,  In hearts that will wait for your story to mend.Adieu, O soldier! Go gentle, bold friend.  The meadow is open, your road without end.

instance_metrics.response: ADIEU, O soldier!  Your boots have pressed the wild clover flat,  and morning, heavy-lidded with grief,  leans against the silent gate.  A mother’s ribbon trembles on your wrist—  faded crimson, her heart’s first blood  offered to the steely dawn.Once, you laughed at thunderstorms,  pocketed medals of thunder in your chest,  and sent paper ships trembling downstream  toward distant fires.  Now, the hush before sun-crest is you,  a hesitant echo on the frost,  a folded letter puckered with worry,  slipped beneath your old pillow.Adieu—such a slender word,  it whistles between fields of poppies and iron,  catching in the furrows of prayers and ploughs,  lingering in the brief spangle of brass at your collar.  The lark still climbs, honey-gold in the haze;  the banners of wheat salute your retreat.O soldier, you stride the horizon’s blade—  a lone stanza breaking the page—  while those who love you stand rooted,  blind to the sun’s glare,  sending you adieu in every tongue of the wind,  wishing, through the ages,  for your shadow’s homecoming.

instance_metrics.response: ADIEU, O soldier!  Beneath the blue and barrel roll of sky,  You turn your gaze to far-off fields unyielding,  Each blade of grass a memory—sharp, alive—  A glimmer caught in boots ripe with leaving.  You do not wave, but your shadow lengthens,  Spilling over wild poppies and broken stones;  Rivers falter, wind holds its trembling breath,  And the village hushes, clutching brittle hopes.  Children, like doves startled at sundown, scatter;  A mother shapes your name with silent lips,  Her sorrow folding neatly with your shirts—  Bravery brushed beside the scent of sage and home.  O, the ragged drumbeat of valediction—  Flag and feather, metal and marrow,  Scarlet with promise and regret—  How we keen your silhouette against sunrise,  Afraid to let the word fall: farewell, godspeed. The apple split, the skin undone,  light burning through leaf’s secret ache.They were overcome by the scarlet hush  of dragonflies pinned in Eden’s air,  by snake’s deft hope, by the pulse and rush  of a world unspooling into care.They were overcome by consequence—  the thump of heart, the hum of bone,  breath fogging glass with innocence,  hands weaving shadow, long alone.Something in the garden’s breast  heaved and sighed beneath their feet:  they wore their nakedness like rest—  and longing hungered in their meat.Overcome by memory’s bite,  by curiosity clothed in grief,  by dust that tangled with delight,  by sun that blazed and made them brief.And so, they wandered—overcome—  by stars uncertain overhead,  by thorn and promise, faith gone dumb,  their trembling lips sealed with unsaid.O Eve, O Adam, love undone—  the world remakes what you began,  Each day we’re overcome as one,  unraveling the gift of man.

They were the beginning of thunder:  muscles tensed with the ache of what’s forbidden,  palms open to the bewildering thrust of a promise  not meant for gods.  When their names cracked in the cool hush  and they donned clothes of sorrow,  every leaf on every tree recoiled in memory—  theirs was the first ache,  the first time beloved became bereft. instance_metrics.response: Adam and Eve were overcome—  not in fire, nor in flood,  but in an orchard’s silent gloom  beneath the tongue’s sharp bud.  The dusk hummed ripe with honeycombs,  temptation dusk, cicada drone,  they plucked the silver-ripened dome  and chewed the flesh down to the stone.  Knowledge unspooled like scarlet yarn  across the grass and into bone—  ankle-deep in moulting dawn  where innocence had flown.  No angel bled upon their lips;  no serpent hissed his claim:  only the weight of what they’d guessed—  the echo in their frame  of other worlds, lost by a breath,  by hunger, by shame’s name.  The garden closed, the sky unwept,  as Adam gazed at Eve and wept  for all the fruit they could not save,  for all the answers softly kept  in the garden’s secret grave.  They wandered out of hallowed shade,  hands held tight, half-afraid:  between them, a gnawing ache—  to be human, to be remade.  Adam and Eve were overcome—  not by sin, but by the ache  of waking to the world’s wide leash—  and the sorrow love must stake.
